headline.main-hed: Christie’s Hong Kong Evening Sale of Asian Art Draws $82 Million

alt-summary-body.p: Buyers snapped up works by Japanese and Southeast Asian artists at Christie’s evening sale in Hong Kong on Saturday totaling 635 million Hong Kong dollars ($82 million), the auction house’s second-highest total in the city for Asian 20th Century and Contemporary Art.
Buyers snapped up works by Japanese and Southeast Asian artists at Christie’s evening sale in Hong Kong totaling $82 million.

headline.main-hed: Christie’s Hong Kong sale of Asian 20th-century and contemporary art drew $82 million
Christie’s Hong Kong Sale Hits $82 Million

summary-body.p: Buyers snapped up works by Japanese and Southeast Asian artists at Christie’s evening sale in Hong Kong totaling $82 million.

headline.main-hed: Christie’s Hong Kong Evening Sale of Asian Art Draws $82 Million
headline.deck: Contemporary and 20th-Century Artists From Japan and Southeast Asia Fare Well

article-body.p: HONG KONG—Buyers snapped up works by Japanese and Southeast Asian artists at a Christie’s evening sale in Hong Kong on Saturday, totaling 635 million Hong Kong dollars (US$82 million), the auction house’s second-highest total in the city for Asian 20th-century and contemporary art.

But demand for some top Chinese artists, including Zeng Fanzhi and Zhang Xiaogang, is cooling, as China’s anticorruption campaign weighs on demand for expensive items, taking some froth out of the art market, according to experts.
Christie’s said 89% of the 81 lots offered were sold at Saturday’s autumn auction. Eleven artists set personal records, including four from Japan, four from Southeast Asia and two from China.

The most expensive painting of the evening was “Potted Peonies” by Chinese-French artist Sanyu (1901-1966). The painting, with a realized price of HK$56.1 million, including commissions, depicts white peonies and black leaves against a dark-brown fiberboard, with small ancient coins scattered like fallen petals near the flower’s white pot, giving the work an auspicious look.
The painting, which was sold to a Taiwanese couple, had a hammer price of HK$49 million, versus a preauction estimate between HK$30 million and HK$40 million.

Sanyu was trained in Chinese calligraphy in his youth and picked up the styles of Picasso and Matisse after moving to France. The French-trained Asian artists have attained “a perfect balance between the East and West,” said Eric Chang, deputy chairman of Asia at Christie’s. “They are becoming more sought-after among collectors.”

list-item.link: Hitler Painting Is Sold for $161,000 at German Auction
After the Fall, Restored to Grace
Collector’s Cousin Makes Last-Minute Claim to Nazi-Tainted Art Trove

article-body.p: Abstract Japanese paintings also sold well. Christie’s introduced the Gutai Art Association, Japan’s 1950s avant-garde movement, as a category for the first time. A dark-blue abstract painting titled “Kaien” by Kazuo Shiraga, who used his feet to execute the work, was sold for HK$23.6 million, including commissions, to Shanghai museum owner Wang Wei, higher than the estimated range of HK$10 million to HK$15 million.

Ms. Wang, with husband Liu Yiqian, has accumulated a vast amount of Chinese revolutionary art, as well as modern Chinese art. In recent years, they have been adding non-Chinese artwork by the likes of Jeff Koons to their collections.
Paintings by artists Le Pho of Vietnam, Cheong Soo Pieng of Singapore and Kim Whan-ki of Korea also did better than expected.

Big names from China, however, failed to meet expectations. Three paintings from Zhang Xiaogang, known for his bloodline series, had hammer prices below estimates. Similarly, bids for paintings by Zeng Fanzhi, known for his mask series, were at or below the low end of estimates.

inset.p: China’s art market has some bubbles.
inset.tagline: Jianping Mei, professor at Cheung Kong Graduate School of Business

article-body.p: “China’s art market has some bubbles,” said Jianping Mei, professor at Cheung Kong Graduate School of Business, who co-established the Mei Moses family of fine-art indexes. “As the money supply slows and wealth gap narrows in China, it’s difficult to repeat past performance.”

As demand for Chinese art has softened, Christie’s has diversified its bets, focusing on pan-Asian and East-meets-West themes, such as on Saturday. “The pan-Asian theme has been a success and the Asian market is still strong,” said Christie’s Mr. Chang.
Earlier this month in New York, collectors bought more than $2 billion of art at auctions at Sotheby’s and Christie’s, a historic high.
Write to Wei Gu at wei.gu@wsj.com
